snippet: Tunisia and Egypt, whose revolts ignited the Arab Spring, provide a dual lesson in the pitfalls and potentials for democracy in the region as they move toward new charters.
abstract: Tunisia and Egypt, whose revolts ignited the Arab Spring, provide contrasting lesson in pitfalls and potentials for democracy in the region as they move toward new charters; Tunisia is poised to approve new constitution that is one of the most liberal in Arab world, while Egypt is seeking to pass referendum that validates military ouster of Mohamed Morsi and gives power and immunity to both military and police.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and CARLOTTA GALL
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo, and Carlotta Gall from Tunis.

lead_paragraph: Tunisia and Egypt, whose revolts ignited the Arab Spring, provide a dual lesson in the pitfalls and potentials for democracy in the region as they move toward new charters.

headline.main: Arab Neighbors Take Split Paths in Constitutions
headline.print_headline: Arab Neighbors Take Split Paths in Constitutions

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
